results.title: Special Project no. 14: Marlo-Mallacoota-Cape Conran
results.brief_description: The Country Roads Board’s Project no. 14 involves the building of a road from Orbost to Marlo. Shows the first section to Cape Conran and difficulties encountered in clearing and leveling the sandy loam. The area opened by the road has great development potential in its attractive surf beaches, bushland and off-shore oil drilling. Photography by Jim Stirling.
results.description: The Country Roads Board’s Project no. 14 involves the building of a road from Orbost to Marlo. results.title: The Burnie story
results.creator_credit: Associated Pulp and Paper Manufacturers and Cine Service
results.brief_description: The township of Burnie on the north-west coast of Tasmania with a population of 14,000 is the centre of the thriving pulp and paper manufacturing industry. This industry started in 1936 and produces from the forests in the surrounding country, not only timber for the building industry but from the timber waste all types of cardboard, and wrapping paper and even high-grade printing paper. The film shows the up-to-date and powerful machinery which is used from the time a tree is felled until the final paper product is shipped from the Burnie wharves. Afforestation is maintained to ensure the raw material will not be exhausted. Photography: Geoffrey Thompson. Narrated by Ray Chapman.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Associated Pulp and Paper Manufacturers and Cine Service

results.title: As long as I can walk
results.brief_description: A report on a Moratorium March held in Melbourne in 1970. Interviews with marchers give insights into personal motives, and show the strong desire for a peaceful settlement of the Vietnam question.

results.title: 11 Steps to Survival
results.creator_credit: Pierre L'Amare, Robert Verrall and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A film demonstrating steps to take in the event of a nuclear attack. Animated drawings show the effects of atomic explosions in the air and at ground level. How wide an area is affected by light and heat flash, radiation and radio-active fall-out is clearly illustrated. How to build or improvise a fall-out shelter, what to stock in it, when to take shelter and how long to stay there are similarly explained.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Pierre L’Amare, Robert Verrall and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Telling tales
results.brief_description:
Telling Tales are real stories told and produced by people with a disability and those who are disadvantaged.

Telling Tales challenges the ‘norms’ as often represented by mainstream film with first person accounts that provide a real opportunity to be seen and heard. The stories explore personal journeys of identity, displacement, relationships, longing and memory.

Telling Tales was produced in partnership with Arts Access and supported by the Department of Human Services and the Deafness Foundation for Telling Tales.

results.title: A different perspective
results.brief_description: ‘I was given a photo pass to the 1994 Big Day Out. From then on, outside my day job I worked as a freelance photographer’. Produced in partnership with Arts Access and supported by the Department of Human Services and the Deafness Foundation for the ACMI Digital Storytelling Workshop ‘Telling Tales’.

results.title: Cardin Street
results.brief_description: A little piece of wood tells a whole story about a house, about home, about friendship. A personal account created by a participant in the ACMI Digital Storytelling Workshop Telling Tales. Produced in partnership with Arts Access and supported by the Department of Human Services and the Deafness Foundation for Telling Tales.

results.title: The Brown dressing gown
results.brief_description: Patric fondly remembers his social worker Julie Wilson who helped him come out of his cocoon and discard his brown dressing gown. This Digital Storytelling project was created in partnership with the Department of Human Services and The Deafness Foundation.

results.title: Synthing
results.brief_description: Synthing is the result of years of exploratory work across disciplines. “The Synthing concept puts expressive and energetic body movement in front of a video camera interface to create an engrossing interplay of music and images within the framework of a cybermedium… a synaesthetic compositional tool”, says Gruchy. Synthing, through its use of real-time navigation and interactive technologies, allows real opportunities for audience interaction.

Synthing, through its use of real-time navigation and interactive technologies, allows real opportunities for audience interaction.

Synthing, through its use of real-time navigation and interactive technologies, allows real opportunities for audience interaction.

production_dates.notes: Extensive Re-encoding required for DVD and synthesiser adaptation
